FacilityName: City of Great Falls Water Treatment Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE
The City of Great Falls and its Public Works Department, which manages the Water Treatment Plant, take safety very seriously.  The City of Great Falls Safety manual states that ? The City of Great Falls is committed to providing and ensuring a safe work environment for all employees, co-workers, and the public by conducting all operations as safely and efficiently as possible.  A comprehensive Safety and Loss Control Program can only be effective if everyone in the organization accepts their responsibility with accountability.?  The Public Works Safety Committee meets monthly and is active in accident review and facility audits.

The Great Falls Water Treatment Plant works with the Great Falls Fire Department and the Local Emergency Planning Committee in preparing for emergency response.  This preparation includes annual reporting of hazardous chemicals, annual inspections by Fire Department personnel and occasional training for responses to major chlorine release events.  The training sessions for response to chlorine leaks are a full scale exercise and take place at the Water Treatment Plant and similar facilities at the Wastewater Treatment Plant.

THE WATER TREATMENT PLANT REGULATED SUBSTANCES
The Great Falls Water Treatment Plant is a conventional surface water treatment plant.  Treatment processes include coagulation, settling, filtration and disinfection, with ammonia added after disinfection to prolong a disinfectant residual in the distribution system.  The primary chemicals involved in the process are aluminum sulfate (a liquid coagulant), chlorine gas (to provide disinfection) and ammonia gas.  Chlorine is the only substance at the treatment plant in sufficient quantity to require regulation.

THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
The Water Treatment Plant staff have developed a prevention program in compliance with EPA?s Risk Management Program as well as OSHA's

Process Safety Management program.  In addition, safety training resulting from the Montana Department of Environmental Quality?s oversight of the facility operation have been in place for years.  All employees, contractors and anyone else that is at the facility for any length of time or will work around the chlorine system is fully informed of the hazards of chlorine, the operation of the alarm system (i.e. what certain alarms mean), and how to safely exit the facility.  As a result, there has never been a reportable chlorine release or a chlorine-related injury at the facility.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
As this update is being prepared, the Water Treatment Plant is upgrading the chlorine system and associated equipment to provide a system that delivers chlorine to the feed facility under a vacuum rather than pressure.  The ventilation system is also being upgraded to provide a scrubber that will eliminate discharge of significant concentrations of chlorine in the case of a leak.  This project is scheduled to be complete in the summer of 2004.
